etymologies: mid 19th century; earliest use found in John Lindley (1799–1865), botanist and horticulturist. From French muscardine from muscardin silkworm affected by this disease, specific use of †muscardin muscadine, so called because the affected silkworms had a chalky appearance similar to that of a musk lozenge

definitions: Any of various fungal diseases affecting silkworms and other insects (more fully "muscardine disease"). Also: any of the fungi, especially of the genera Beauveria and Metarhizium, causing these diseases (more fully "muscardine fungus").
